conclusion: The problem involves calculating the work done by the frictional force on an object as it is transported from point M to point N on a conveyor belt.
The frictional force acting on the object is given by F_f = μmg, where μ is the coefficient of kinetic friction, m is the mass of the object, and g is the acceleration due to gravity.
The acceleration of the object is calculated as a = F_f / m = μg. Substituting μ = 0.3 and g = 10 m/s², we get a = 3 m/s².
The time taken for the object to reach the speed of the conveyor belt is determined using v = u + at. Substituting v = 6 m/s, u = 0, and a = 3 m/s², we get t = 2 s.
The distance traveled by the object during the acceleration phase is calculated using s = ut + (1/2)at². Substituting u = 0, a = 3 m/s², and t = 2 s, we get s = 6 m.
The remaining distance traveled by the object after reaching the speed of the conveyor belt is calculated as L_2 = L_1 - s. Substituting L_1 = 10 m and s = 6 m, we get L_2 = 4 m.
The time taken to travel the remaining distance is calculated as t' = L_2 / v. Substituting L_2 = 4 m and v = 6 m/s, we get t' = 2/3 s.
The work done by the frictional force is calculated as W = F_f * s. Substituting F_f = μmg = 9 N and s = 6 m, we get W = 54 J.
The work done by the frictional force of the conveyor belt on the object as it is transported from point M to point N is 54 J.
